test.input: Lungs/Airways/Pleura : Patent central tracheobronchial tree (An anatomical structure comprising of trachea, bronchi, and bronchioles that terminate with the alveolar ducts, sacs, and alveoli.). Significantly improved pulmonary metastatic disease (Pathological processes involving any part of the LUNG.). For example, a 5 mm nodule at the left lung apex (series 5, image 94), is decreased from 9 mm on prior exam. An 11 mm nodule at the right lung base previously measured 15 mm. No pneumonia (Infection of the lung often accompanied by inflammation.) or pulmonary edema (Excessive accumulation of extravascular fluid in the lung, an indication of a serious underlying disease or disorder.). No pleural effusion (Presence of fluid in the pleural cavity resulting from excessive transudation or exudation from the pleural surfaces.) or pneumothorax (An accumulation of air or gas in the PLEURAL CAVITY, which may occur spontaneously or as a result of trauma or a pathological process.). Mediastinum/Lymph nodes: No thoracic adenopathy. Calcified left hilar lymph nodes (They are oval or bean shaped bodies (1 - 30 mm in diameter) located along the lymphatic system.) are noted. Prior thyroidectomy (Surgical removal of the thyroid gland.). Heart (The hollow, muscular organ that maintains the circulation of the blood.) and Vessels (Any of the tubular vessels conveying the blood (arteries, arterioles, capillaries, venules, and veins).): Right IJ chemotherapy port terminates at the superior cavoatrial junction. The heart (The hollow, muscular organ that maintains the circulation of the blood.) is normal in size. There is no pericardial effusion (Fluid accumulation within the PERICARDIUM.). There are moderate atherosclerotic calcifications of the coronary arteries (A principal artery that originates in the aorta.). The great vessels (Any of the tubular vessels conveying the blood (arteries, arterioles, capillaries, venules, and veins).) are normal in caliber. Upper Abdomen: Please see separately dictated report for CT (A type of psychotherapy utilized to treat different forms of mental disorders.The treatment involves the identification of unhelpful or destructive patterns of thinking and behaviors and the subsequent replacement with behaviors that are beneficial and constructive.) of the abdomen and pelvis (The space or compartment surrounded by the pelvic girdle (bony pelvis).) performed on the same day. Osseous structures and Soft Tissues: No aggressive bone lesions.
labels: Spread of cancer to the lungs looks better than before. A fingernail sized growth in the bottom of the right lung is smaller than before. Lymph nodes in the left lung are hardened. The thyroid has been removed.

test.input: Lungs/Airways/Pleura : There is interval stability of a dominant left lower lobe soft tissue mass measuring 5.8 x 3.7 cm (series 5, image 288). An unchanged left upper lobe (The smaller lobe of the left lung, situated above and in front the oblique fissure, which includes the apex.) paravertebral soft tissue mass measures 8.8 x 5.5 x 5.0 cm (CC (Derivative of 7-dehydroxycholesterol formed by ULTRAVIOLET RAYS breaking of the C9-C10 bond.), AP (An enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of an orthophosphoric monoester and water to an alcohol and orthophosphate.), Trans), on series 5, image 131 and series 606, image 49. There are multiple additional unchanged pulmonary nodules measuring up to 1.5 cm, for instance in the right lower lobe (The lobe of the right lung situated below the oblique fissure.) on series 5, image 286; and right upper lobe (The lobe of the right lung, situated above the horizontal fissure, which includes the apex.) on series 5, image 154. Left upper lobe (The smaller lobe of the left lung, situated above and in front the oblique fissure, which includes the apex.) postradiation changes are seen. There is stable narrowing of the left mainstem bronchus (One of the two main bronchi.). Interval increased pleural effusions (Presence of fluid in the pleural cavity resulting from excessive transudation or exudation from the pleural surfaces.) with stable pleural nodularity and 2 cm right pleural metastatic nodule on series 5, image 330. Mediastinum/Lymph nodes: There are stably enlarged cardiophrenic nodes (A lymph node located in the angle between the heart and diaphragm.), measuring up to 1.8 cm in short axis. Additionally, a right lower paratracheal node (A lymph node located adjacent to the trachea within the mediastinum.) measures 1.1 cm, unchanged. There is a right thyroid punctate calcification. A small hiatal hernia (STOMACH herniation located at or near the diaphragmatic opening for the ESOPHAGUS, the esophageal hiatus.) is stable. Heart (The hollow, muscular organ that maintains the circulation of the blood.) and Vessels (Any of the tubular vessels conveying the blood (arteries, arterioles, capillaries, venules, and veins).): The heart (The hollow, muscular organ that maintains the circulation of the blood.) appears normal in size. No pericardial effusion (Fluid accumulation within the PERICARDIUM.). The ascending aorta (The portion of the aorta that emerges from the left ventricle and precedes the aortic arch.) is ectatic, measuring 3.8 cm. The blood pool (acquired during repeated cardiac cycles at specific times in the cycle, using an electrocardiographic synchronizer or gating device.) is hypodense relative to myocardium, suggestive of anemia (A reduction in the number of circulating ERYTHROCYTES or in the quantity of HEMOGLOBIN.). Upper Abdomen: Refer to CT abdomen/pelvis obtained same day Osseous structures and Soft Tissues: There are stable compression deformities present in the superior thoracic spine, transfixed by a posterior hardware. There are multiple chest wall subcutaneous masses, some demonstrating interval growth, for instance an anterior scapular (a flat triangular bone, a pair of which form the back part of the shoulder girdle.) soft tissue mass measures 3.1 x 2.4 cm, previously 2.8 x 2.2 cm. Stable left superior scapular (a flat triangular bone, a pair of which form the back part of the shoulder girdle.) soft tissue mass measuring 3.6 x 2.7 cm.

No pleural effusion (Presence of fluid in the pleural cavity resulting from excessive transudation or exudation from the pleural surfaces.) or pneumothorax (An accumulation of air or gas in the PLEURAL CAVITY, which may occur spontaneously or as a result of trauma or a pathological process.). Central airways (The part of the respiratory system between the nose or mouth and the lungs.) are clear. Mediastinum/Lymph nodes: Increase in size of multiple right axillary and subpectoral lymph nodes (An axillary lymph node located along the lower edge of the pectoralis minor.), for example a subpectoral node measuring up to 1.2 cm short axis in series 4 image 106 which previously measured 0.8 cm at this level. There are also increasingly prominent but subcentimeter left axillary lymph nodes. Increasing right hilar adenopathy measuring up to 1.7 cm short axis. Increasing subcarinal lymph nodes (A lymph node located in the thoracic cavity between the lungs.) measuring up to 1.6 and meter short axis. Increasing periaortic adenopathy measuring up to 1.3 cm short axis. Normal thyroid (Pathological processes involving the THYROID GLAND.). Heart (The hollow, muscular organ that maintains the circulation of the blood.) and Vessels (Any of the tubular vessels conveying the blood (arteries, arterioles, capillaries, venules, and veins).): Normal cardiac size. No pericardial effusion (Fluid accumulation within the PERICARDIUM.). Normal course and caliber of the thoracic aorta (The portion of the descending aorta proceeding from the arch of the aorta and extending to the DIAPHRAGM, eventually connecting to the ABDOMINAL AORTA.). Pulmonary artery (The short wide vessel arising from the conus arteriosus of the right ventricle and conveying unaerated blood to the lungs.) is normal size. Upper Abdomen: See separate dictated abdominal CT (A type of psychotherapy utilized to treat different forms of mental disorders.The treatment involves the identification of unhelpful or destructive patterns of thinking and behaviors and the subsequent replacement with behaviors that are beneficial and constructive.) report for findings below the level of the diaphragm (The musculofibrous partition that separates the THORACIC CAVITY from the ABDOMINAL CAVITY.). Osseous structures and Soft Tissues: No aggressive bone lesions. Routine age-related degenerative (Disturbance of cell integrity and deterioration of normal tissue, cells or organs.) changes throughout the thoracic spine (The vertebrae of the thoracic spine, numbered one through twelve in man.).
